Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CT-M: Privacy, Compliance and Information Risk in Complex Organizational Processes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern organizations, such as businesses, non-profits, government
agencies, and universities, collect and use personal information from
a range of sources, shared with specific expectations about how it
will be managed and used. Accordingly, they must find ways to comply
with expectations, which may be complex and varied, as well as with
relevant privacy laws and regulations, while they minimize
operational risk and carry out core functions of the organization
efficiently and effectively. Designing organizational processes to
manage personal information is one of the greatest challenges facing
organizations (see, e.g. a recent survey by Deloitte and the Ponemon
Institute [TI07]), with far-reaching implications for every
individual whose personal information is available to modern
organizations, i.e. all of us.

This project responds to these challenges by developing methods,
algorithms and prototype tools for integrating privacy, compliance,
and risk evaluation into complex organizational processes. It
explores, articulates and characterizes formally the scope and nature
of privacy-expectations of stakeholders as well as those of key
regulations, such as HIPAA, GLBA, COPPA, BASEL 2, and Sarbanes-Oxley
(SOX). It incorporates the diverse perspectives and areas of
expertise of its multidisciplinary research team, which includes
three computer scientists, one philosopher, and collaborating
researchers from IBM. This industry connection facilitates
interaction with product teams that have served complex organizations
concerned with business process integrity, information security,
privacy, and information risk management. The research builds on
"contextual integrity" (a philosophical account of privacy) as well
as language and risk-based methods for privacy policy specification
and enforcement. Extensive training and educational opportunities are
provided to undergraduate and graduate students and research results
integrated into courses at CMU, NYU, Stanford, and UPenn.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modern organizations, such as businesses, non-profits, government agencies, and universities, collect and use personal information from a range of sources, shared with specific expectations about how it will be managed and used. Accordingly, they must find ways to comply with expectations, which may be complex and varied, as well as with relevant privacy laws and regulations, while they minimize operational risk and carry out core functions of the organization efficiently and effectively. Designing organizational processes to manage personal information is one of the greatest challenges facing organizations, with far-reaching implications for every individual whose personal information is available to modern organizations, i.e., all of us. To mitigate privacy concerns, organizations are required to respect privacy laws in regulated sectors and to adhere to self-declared privacy policies in self-regulated sectors. Enforcing these kinds of privacy policies in organizations is difficult because privacy laws and enterprise policies typically identify a complex set of conditions governing the disclosure of personal information. This project responded to these challenges by developing methods, algorithms and prototype tools for integrating privacy, compliance, and risk evaluation into complex organizational processes. 

This project developed specific methods, algorithms, tools and worked examples related to healthcare privacy. Compliance with HIPAA, HITECH and related state laws is mandatory for healthcare organizations and their business associates. There are many vendors that strive to help healthcare organizations with HIPAA compliance, suggesting that there is a market demand for technology to automate policy compliance checking. The advanced a logical representation of federal and state laws that can be used to support applications such as: automated compliance checking for complex multi-layer policies, compliance-aware medical messaging systems,  HIPAA training/education, and identification of interesting edge cases and conflicts in applicable privacy law. Our efforts with this project have led to the following observations: (a) A subset of healthcare privacy laws can be modeled using first-order logic languages such as Datalog. (b) Some laws are contextual in nature, and they may depend on context, roles, norms, purposes and beliefs. These are modeled as parameters to the policy checker. (c) When more than one state/federal law may apply, the more specific law takes precedence. (d) Automated algorithms may identify surprising cases where some parties may have unintended access to information.

The Stanford contingent of this project collaborated with U Penn on the core topic of formalizing heath information privacy and analyzing the properties and consequences of formalized policy. Collaboration with CMU was based on CMU work on audit and purpose for similarly formalized healthcare policy.  Exploring new applications of essentially similar concepts and approach, collaboration with NYU involved consultation on privacy issues for court records and initial exploration of privacy issues related to online education.
